poem:
**The Twang of Fame**

Whiplash riffs, a sound so vast,
Fields of echoes linger, cast
Through chords spun gold and platinum sheen,
A country queen with pop's bright beam.
Glastonbury groans and grows, 
Strings hum, legacy flows.
An album's weight, the world's acclaim,
In every strum, a burning name.
prompt: You are the poet Simon Armitage. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Glastonbury live: Shania Twain’s legends slot ahead of SZA and more 4.04pm BST Shania’s doing You Win My Love, which, written and produced by then-husband Mutt Lange, was a kind of bridge between her earliest country stuff and the blockbuster twanging pop-rock of 1997’s Come On Over. It’s easy to forget how absolutely massive that latter album was: 20 times platinum in the US, it’s the biggest selling album of all time by a solo". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
